Unlike the debate in Washington, which is completely at a standstill, at the state level there is much more of an emphasis on practical solutions and there's more of a willingness go get beyond the ideological.
So I think there's much more of an openness to compromise at the state level.
But there are critics.
Business groups say the insurance mandate would hurt Massachusetts companies.
Others doubt there'll be enough money to help the poor get the coverage they'll be required to buy.
And advocates for a simpler, single-payer approach say the plan does nothing to control the runaway costs of a complicated system of private insurance.
So says Alice Rothchild, president of the Alliance to Defend Health Care.
The problem is that there's a huge bureaucracy that has grown up to decide what your benefits are, and it's a huge waste that could be spent on actually providing health care.
So unless the costs of producing the health care are reduced or controlled, the amount of health care we get is going to be less and less and less.
Guilty, guilty, guilty.
It's all true.
It is.
Again, John McDonough of Health Care For All.
Despite that admission, he supports the House plan because he says there is no political will to dismantle the current system of private health insurance.
And I refuse to accept the notion that if somehow we could get 500,000 uninsured in Massachusetts covered, that that's chump change.
(Soundbite of printer)
At the Codman Square Health Center in Dorchester, CEO Bill Walczak reluctantly agrees.
He'd like to see a simpler, single-payer system, but he also wants to see his patients get the coverage they need.
And that's really, really important.
Maybe someday we'll be able to have a system of care that eliminates a lot of the bureaucracy and a lot of the administrative overhead and goes to a single payer.
But for right now this is a major step forward.
Anthony Brooks, NPR News, Boston.

I'm Laura Sullivan, in for Guy Raz.
People without health insurance have depended on free clinics for years, but with the passage of health care reform, more than 30 million people are expected to gain health insurance.
The law goes before the Supreme Court this week, but health providers are already gearing up for a surge in insured patients.
As Elana Gordon of member station KCUR in Kansas City reports, that leaves free clinics in unchartered territory.
Around the country, hundreds of free clinics have been established over the last 50 years to treat patients like Patsy Duarte.
Hmm, that's no good, 172 over 85.
Way too much.
Yeah.
How are you feeling with that?
Do you get a headache?
Duarte's getting her blood pressure checked at Duchesne Clinic in Kansas City, Kansas, that's housed in an old parish school.
She's been coming here for years for hypertension, diabetes and other health issues.
I have no insurance.
I have no other means of going to a doctor.
The last time that my husband went to a doctor, it was like $85 just for the visit.
Duarte says medical conditions limit her ability to work, and the couple's combined income is about $15,000 a year.
The bad economy, the loss of jobs and health insurance has also meant more people are turning to the clinic, according to director, Amy Falk.
We've been kind of caught in the perfect storm of you have so many people needing care that can't get care, but at the same time, funding, you know, has been held level or in some cases decreased.
So while you'd like to ramp up, this is not the economic time to do that.
While uninsured people can and do go to community health centers and hospitals, free clinics are the only place where there's no fear of a bill.
Despite the expansion of Medicaid to an additional 16 million people, free clinics expect to still be an important part of the health care safety net.
Nicole Lamoureux Busby, head of the National Association of Free and Charitable Clinics, says over 20 million people still won't have coverage.
And Lamoureux Busby says many clinics will have a role in helping patients figure out the new system.
It sounds great to have everyone be eligible between 2014 and 2019, but there's not this magic potion or a magic wand that's going to get people signed up.
Somebody's going to have to help them.
We're going to have to explain now a very complicated system that quite frankly ignored many of our patients in the past.
Duchesne free clinic director, Amy Falk, says the clinic's already been responding to a changing health system by trying to be more of a primary care center for patients.
The clinic's thought a lot about the situation and the access challenges patients already face.
I don't think we can stay as we are.
I think we have to grow within our environment.
Falk says the clinic has decided to take Medicaid and private insurance if health coverage expands in the future.
It will totally change the culture and structure of this clinic, having never had to do these things and building the infrastructure, one to put in place but just how we do our daily workflow.
It will change.
Taking Medicaid and private insurance could alter the nature of free clinics who rely on volunteers like Dr. Glenn Hodges of the Health Partnership Clinic in nearby Johnson County.
DR.
GLENN HODGES: I'm a medical missionary three miles from where I live, taking care of people in my neighborhood.
Dr.
Hodges has been a happy volunteer at the Health Partnership Clinic since he retired from the VA more than 10 years ago.
This clinic is making some sweeping changes that will include taking Medicaid and private coverage and qualifying for more federal funds.
The white-bearded Hodges, who's also a master rose gardener, says he plans to stay with the clinic.
He and most other volunteers will focus on patients who don't have coverage.
Staff will focus on those with coverage.
Sheffield, the husband and father - attentive or consumed with his career?
Detective Erin Bell chases down informants and travels through parts of Los Angeles rarely seen on film.

In fact, the same location manager from ""La La Land"" scouted sites for ""Destroyer"" - skid row, a colossal self-storage facility between freeways, an old Chinese diner in the gritty MacArthur Park area.
(SOUNDBITE OF ENGINE REVVING)
As we drive around revisiting locations, director Karyn Kusama gives her vision of LA.
Chaos, beauty, ugliness, awe-inspiring transcendental grace.
What makes Los Angeles so interesting is it's not just, frankly, a beautiful city.
In fact, there are many parts of it that are quite hard to look at, and then you can find yourself in some sort of pocket of paradise.
Kusama takes me and my editor Nina Gregory to a hidden patch of land where she shot a chase scene at night.
We climb a rickety wooden staircase to get to a ridge in Elysian Park.
So from here, you can see the Hollywood sign.
